standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $6$ that may be useful:  - $6 \times 3 = 18$ - $6 \times 5 = 30$ - $6 \times 10 = 60$
What multiple of $6$ is less than $2{,}167$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $2{,}167$ into $\purpleD{300}$ sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{1{,}800}}&\purpleD{300}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{300} = \blueE{1{,}800}\\ &367 \end{array}$  We have $367$ left.

Let's divide $367$ into $\purpleD{50}$ more sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}800}&300\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{300}}&\purpleD{50}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{50} = \blueE{300}\\ &67 \end{array}$  We have $67$ left.

Let's divide $67$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}800}&300\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&50\\ &67\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{60}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{60}\\ &7 \end{array}$  We have $7$ left.

Let's divide $7$ into $\purpleD{1}$ more six.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}800}&300\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&50\\ &67\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{60}&10\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{6}\\ &1 \end{array}$  We have $1$ left.  That is less than $6$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)2{,}167}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}800}&\purpleD{300}\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&\purpleD{50}\\ &67\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{60}&\purpleD{10}\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{361} \end{array}$  $\purpleE{300} + \purpleE{50} + \purpleE{10} + \purpleE{1}= \greenE{361}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{1}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{361}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{1}\\ 6\overline{\Big)2{,}167}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $7$ that may be useful:  - $7 \times 3 = 21$ - $7 \times 4 = 28$ - $7 \times 5 = 35$
What multiple of $7$ is less than $276$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)276} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $276$ into $\purpleD{30}$ sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)276}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{210}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{210}\\ &66 \end{array}$  We have $66$ left.

Let's divide $66$ into $\purpleD{9}$ more sevens because $9\times 7=63$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)276}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{210}&30\\ &66\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{63}}&\purpleD{9}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{9} = \blueE{63}\\ &3 \end{array}$  We have $3$ left. That is less than $7$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)276}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{210}&\purpleD{30}\\ &66\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{63}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{9}}\\ &\goldE{3}&\greenE{39} \end{array}$  $\purpleE{30} + \purpleE{9}= \greenE{39}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{3}$.
$276 \div 7 =\greenE{39}$ remainder $\goldE{3}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $9$ that may be useful:  - $9 \times 3 = 27$ - $9 \times 4 = 36$ - $9 \times 5 = 45$
What multiple of $9$ is less than $393$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)393} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $393$ into $\purpleD{40}$ nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)393}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{360}}&\purpleD{40}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{40} = \blueE{360}\\ &33 \end{array}$  We have $33$ left.

Let's divide $33$ into $\purpleD{3}$ more nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)393}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{360}&40\\ &33\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{27}}&\purpleD{3}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{3} = \blueE{27}\\ &6 \end{array}$  We have $6$ left.  That is less than $9$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)393}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{360}&\purpleD{40}\\ &33\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{27}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{3}}\\ &\goldE{6}&\greenE{43} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{40} + \purpleD{3}= \greenE{43}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{6}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{43}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{6}\\ 9\overline{\Big)393}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $8$ that may be useful:  - $8 \times 2 = 16$ - $8 \times 7 = 56$ - $8 \times 10 = 80$
What multiple of $8$ is less than $5{,}698$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)5{,}698} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $5{,}698$ into $\purpleD{700}$ eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)5{,}698}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{5{,}600}}&\purpleD{700}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{700} = \blueE{5{,}600}\\ &98 \end{array}$  We have $98$ left.

Let's divide $98$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)5{,}698}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}600}&700\\ &98\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{80}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{80}\\ &18 \end{array}$  We have $18$ left.

Let's divide $18$ into $\purpleD{2}$ more eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)5{,}698}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}600}&700\\ &98\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{80}&10\\ &18\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{16}}&\purpleD{2}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{2} = \blueE{16}\\ &2 \end{array}$  We have $2$ left.  That is less than $8$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)5{,}698}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}600}&\purpleD{700}\\ &98\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{80}&\purpleD{10}\\ &18\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{16}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{2}}\\ &\goldE{2}&\greenE{712} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{700} + \purpleD{10} + \purpleD{2}= \greenE{712}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{2}$.
$5{,}698 \div 8 = \greenE{712}$ remainder $\goldE{2}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $8$ that may be useful:  - $8 \times 2 = 16$ - $8 \times 5 = 40$ - $8 \times 10 = 80$
What multiple of $8$ is less than $200$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)200} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $200$ into $\purpleD{20}$ eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)200}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{160}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{160}\\ &40\\ \end{array}$  We have $40$ left.

Let's divide $40$ into $\purpleD{5}$ more eights since  $5\times8=40$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)200}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&20\\ &40\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{40}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{40}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)200}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&\purpleD{20}\\ &40\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{40}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{25} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{25}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$200 \div 8 =\greenE{25}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $7$ that may be useful:  - $7 \times 7 = 49$ - $7 \times 8 = 56$ - $7 \times 10 = 70$
What multiple of $7$ is less than $7{,}055$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)7055} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $7{,}055$ into $\purpleD{1{,}000}$ sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)7{,}055}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{7{,}000}}&\purpleD{1{,}000}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{1000} = \blueE{7{,}000}\\ &55 \end{array}$  We have $55$ left.

Let's divide $55$ into $\purpleD{7}$ more sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)7{,}055}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{7{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &55\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{49}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{49}\\ &6 \end{array}$  We have $6$ left. That is less than $7$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)7{,}055}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{7{,}000}&\purpleD{1{,}000}\\ &55\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{49}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{6}&\greenE{1{,}007} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{1{,}000} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{1{,}007}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{6}$.
$7{,}055 \div 7 =\greenE{1{,}007}$ remainder $\goldE{6}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $6$ that may be useful:  - $6 \times 2 = 12$ - $6 \times 5 = 30$ - $6 \times 10 = 60$
What multiple of $6$ is less than $906$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)906} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $906$ into $\purpleD{100}$ sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)906}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{600}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{600}\\ &306 \end{array}$  We have $306$ left.

Let's divide $306$ into $\purpleD{50}$ more sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)906}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{600}&100\\ &306\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{300}}&\purpleD{50}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{50} = \blueE{300}\\ &6\\ \end{array}$  We have $6$ left.

Let's divide $6$ into $\purpleD{1}$ more six.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)906}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{600}&100\\ &306\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&50\\ &6\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{6}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)906}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{600}&\purpleD{100}\\ &306\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&\purpleD{50}\\ &6\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{151} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{50} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{151}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{151}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 6\overline{\Big)906}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $9$ that may be useful:  - $9 \times 2 = 18$ - $9 \times 4 = 36$ - $9 \times 5 = 45$
What multiple of $9$ is less than $4{,}008$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)4{,}008} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $4{,}008$ into $\purpleD{400}$ nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)4{,}008}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{3{,}600}}&\purpleD{400}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{400} = \blueE{3{,}600}\\ &408 \end{array}$  We have $408$ left.

Let's divide $408$ into $\purpleD{40}$ more nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)4{,}008}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&400\\ &408\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{360}}&\purpleD{40}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{40} = \blueE{360}\\ &48 \end{array}$  We have $48$ left.

Let's divide $48$ into $\purpleD{5}$ more nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)4{,}008}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&400\\ &408\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{360}&40\\ &48\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{45}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{45}\\ &3 \end{array}$  We have $3$ left.  That is less than $9$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)4{,}008}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&\purpleD{400}\\ &408\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{360}&\purpleD{40}\\ &48\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{45}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{3}&\greenE{445} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{400} + \purpleD{40} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{445}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{3}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{445}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{3}\\ 9\overline{\Big)4{,}008}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $9$ that may be useful:  - $9 \times 3 = 27$ - $9 \times 4 = 36$ - $9 \times 10 = 90$
What multiple of $9$ is less than $135$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)135} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $135$ into $\purpleD{10}$ nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)135}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{90}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{90}\\ &45 \end{array}$  We have $45$ left.

Let's divide $45$ into $\purpleD{5}$ more nines since  $5\times9=45$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)135}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&10\\ &45\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{45}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{45}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)135}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&\purpleD{10}\\ &45\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{45}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{15} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{10} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{15}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$135 \div 9 =\greenE{15}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $6$ that may be useful:  - $6 \times 4 = 24$ - $6 \times 5 = 30$ - $6 \times 10 = 60$
What multiple of $6$ is less than $8{,}466$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $8{,}466$ into $\purpleD{1{,}000}$ sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6{,}000}}&\purpleD{1{,}000}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{1{,}000} = \blueE{6{,}000}\\ &2{,}466 \end{array}$  We have $2{,}466$ left.

Let's divide $2{,}466$ into $\purpleD{400}$ more sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}466\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}400}}&\purpleD{400}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{400} = \blueE{2{,}400}\\ &66 \end{array}$  We have $66$ left.

Let's divide $66$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}466\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}400}&400\\ &66\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{60}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{60}\\ &6 \end{array}$  We have $6$ left.

Let's divide $6$ into $\purpleD{1}$ more six.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}466\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}400}&400\\ &66\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{60}&10\\ &6\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{6}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)8{,}466}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}000}&\purpleD{1{,}000}\\ &2{,}466\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}400}&\purpleD{400}\\ &66\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{60}&\purpleD{10}\\ &6\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{1{,}411} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{1000} + \purpleD{400} + \purpleD{10} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{1{,}411}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$8{,}466 \div 6 =\greenE{1{,}411}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $8$ that may be useful:  - $8 \times 10 = 80$ - $8 \times 2 = 16$ - $8 \times 5 = 40$
What multiple of $8$ is less than $392$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)392} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $392$ into $\purpleD{20}$ eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)392}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{160}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{160}\\ &232 \end{array}$  We have $232$ left.

Let's divide $232$ into $\purpleD{20}$ more eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)392}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&20\\ &232\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{160}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{160}\\ &72 \end{array}$  We have $72$ left.

Let's divide $72$ into $\purpleD{9}$ more eights since  $8\times9=72$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)392}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&20\\ &232\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&20\\ &72\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{72}}&\purpleD{9}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{9} = \blueE{72}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)392}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&\purpleD{20}\\ &232\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&\purpleD{20}\\ &72\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{72}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{9}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{49} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20}+ \purpleD{20} + \purpleD9 = \greenE{49}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$8\overline{\Big)392} = \greenE{49} $ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $7$ that may be useful:  - $7 \times 3 = 27$ - $7 \times 5 = 35$ - $7 \times 9 = 63$
What multiple of $7$ is less than $2{,}758$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)2{,}758} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $2{,}758$ into $\purpleD{300}$ sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)2{,}758}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}100}}&\purpleD{300}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{300} = \blueE{2{,}100}\\ &658 \end{array}$  We have $658$ left.

Let's divide $658$ into $\purpleD{90}$ more sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)2{,}758}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}100}&300\\ &658\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{630}}&\purpleD{90}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{90} = \blueE{630}\\ &28 \end{array}$  We have $28$ left.

Let's divide $28$ into $\purpleD{4}$ more sevens since  $4\times7=28$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)2{,}758}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}100}&300\\ &658\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{630}&90\\ &28\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{28}}&\purpleD{4}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{4} = \blueE{28}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)2{,}758}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}100}&\purpleD{300}\\ &658\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{630}&\purpleD{90}\\ &28\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{28}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{394}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{300} + \purpleD{90} + \purpleD{4}= \greenE{394}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$7\overline{\Big)2{,}758} =  \greenE{394} $ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $9$ that may be useful:  - $9 \times 2 = 18$ - $9 \times 4 = 36$ - $9 \times 10 = 90$
What multiple of $9$ is less than $3{,}618$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)3{,}618} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $3{,}618$ into $\purpleD{400}$ nines.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)3{,}618}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{3{,}600}}&\purpleD{400}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{400} = \blueE{3{,}600}\\ &18 \end{array}$  We have $18$ left.

Let's divide $18$ into $\purpleD{2}$ more nines since  $2\times9=18$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{9}&\overline{\Big)3{,}618}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&400\\ &18\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{18}}&\purpleD{2}&\maroonD{9} \times \purpleD{2} = \blueE{18}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {9}&\overline{\Big)3{,}618}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&\purpleD{400}\\ &18\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{18}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{2}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{402} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{400} + \purpleD{2}= \greenE{402}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{402}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 9\overline{\Big)3{,}618}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $7$ that may be useful:  - $7 \times 5 = 35$ - $7 \times 6 = 42$ - $7 \times 10 = 70$
What multiple of $7$ is less than $741$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)741} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $741$ into $\purpleD{100}$ sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)741}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{700}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{700}\\ &41 \end{array}$  We have $41$ left.

Let's divide $41$ into $\purpleD{5}$ more sevens.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{7}&\overline{\Big)741}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&100\\ &41\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{35}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{7} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{35}\\ &6 \end{array}$  We have $6$ left.  That is less than $7$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {7}&\overline{\Big)741}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&\purpleD{100}\\ &41\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{35}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{6}&\greenE{105} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{105}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{6}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{105}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{6}\\ 7\overline{\Big)741}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $8$ that may be useful:  - $8 \times 4 = 32$ - $8 \times 6 = 48$ - $8 \times 10 = 80$
What multiple of $8$ is less than $4{,}832$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)4{,}832} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $4{,}832$ into $\purpleD{600}$ eights.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)4{,}832}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{4{,}800}}&\purpleD{600}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{600} = \blueE{4{,}800}\\ &32 \end{array}$  We have $32$ left.

Let's divide $32$ into $\purpleD{4}$ more eights since  $4\times8=32$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{8}&\overline{\Big)4{,}832}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}800}&600\\ &32\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{32}}&\purpleD{4}&\maroonD{8} \times \purpleD{4} = \blueE{32}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {8}&\overline{\Big)4{,}832}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}800}&\purpleD{600}\\ &32\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{32}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{604} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{600} + \purpleD{4}= \greenE{604}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$4{,}832 \div 8 =\greenE{604}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $6$ that may be useful:  - $6 \times 7 = 42$ - $6 \times 9 = 54$ - $6 \times 10 = 60$
What multiple of $6$ is less than $543$?  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)543} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $543$ into $\purpleD{90}$ sixes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{6}&\overline{\Big)543}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{540}}&\purpleD{90}&\maroonD{6} \times \purpleD{90} = \blueE{540}\\ &3\\ \end{array}$  We have $3$ left.  That is less than $6$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients (there is only one this time) to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {6}&\overline{\Big)543}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{540}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{90}}\\ &\goldE{3}&\greenE{90} \end{array}$  The quotient is $\greenE{90}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{3}$.
$543 \div 6 =\greenE{90}$ remainder $\goldE{3}$
